repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Fix #21422

Adds as well {visual}@{register} to apply register into each line

Pending
- [x] use @@ as OP_REGREPLAY

comment_data.body:
Nit, but I think it would make more sense to refer to this as code commands:

```suggestion
‚Ä¢ `Q` now repeats a macro for each line of visual selection.
‚Ä¢ `@` now repeats the indicated macro for each line of visual selection.
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -281,6 +281,10 @@ The following changes to existing APIs or features add new behavior.
   Note that syntax highlighting of code examples requires a matching parser
   and may be affected by custom queries.
 
+
+‚Ä¢ "Q" now repeats a macro for each line of visual selection.
+‚Ä¢ "@" now repeats the indicated macro for each line of visual selection.

comment_data.body:
Adding a new operator is an interesting approach. That's very rare, which raises questions, but OTOH macro replay is fundamental enough that could make sense.

But these don't behave as operators so I still am doubtful. `Q` especially is not an operator.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -139,6 +141,8 @@ static char opchars[][3] = {
   { 'g', '@', OPF_CHANGE },              // OP_FUNCTION
   { Ctrl_A, NUL, OPF_CHANGE },           // OP_NR_ADD
   { Ctrl_X, NUL, OPF_CHANGE },           // OP_NR_SUB
+  { 'Q', NUL, OPF_LINES },               // OP_REGREPLAY
+  { '@', NUL, OPF_LINES },               // OP_ATREGREPLAY

comment_data.body: looks almost identical to the above function. can they be deduped

I saw in the closed PR inside the issue you linked an implementation using the remapping. You mentioned that would be ideal to change [the core C code](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/22048#discussion_r1111348103). This way i thought it made more sense to address both the @ and the Q, as well as allowing '@x' register macro replay.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -139,6 +141,8 @@ static char opchars[][3] = {
   { 'g', '@', OPF_CHANGE },              // OP_FUNCTION
   { Ctrl_A, NUL, OPF_CHANGE },           // OP_NR_ADD
   { Ctrl_X, NUL, OPF_CHANGE },           // OP_NR_SUB
+  { 'Q', NUL, OPF_LINES },               // OP_REGREPLAY
+  { '@', NUL, OPF_LINES },               // OP_ATREGREPLAY

comment_data.body:
~~Operators work with motions and text objects, not only visual mode. Does this PR implement that?~~

Edit: this might be fine. However it could have weird implications, e.g. `:help v:operator` might return "Q" which isn't really correct.

Is there a way to implement it without defining it as an operator?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -139,6 +141,8 @@ static char opchars[][3] = {
   { 'g', '@', OPF_CHANGE },              // OP_FUNCTION
   { Ctrl_A, NUL, OPF_CHANGE },           // OP_NR_ADD
   { Ctrl_X, NUL, OPF_CHANGE },           // OP_NR_SUB
+  { 'Q', NUL, OPF_LINES },               // OP_REGREPLAY
+  { '@', NUL, OPF_LINES },               // OP_ATREGREPLAY

comment_data.body: I'll be looking into it right now. üëç
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -139,6 +141,8 @@ static char opchars[][3] = {
   { 'g', '@', OPF_CHANGE },              // OP_FUNCTION
   { Ctrl_A, NUL, OPF_CHANGE },           // OP_NR_ADD
   { Ctrl_X, NUL, OPF_CHANGE },           // OP_NR_SUB
+  { 'Q', NUL, OPF_LINES },               // OP_REGREPLAY
+  { '@', NUL, OPF_LINES },               // OP_ATREGREPLAY

comment_data.body:
Justin, I managed to handle the `Q` logic in the `OP_ATREGREPLAY` operator, so the `Q` operator by itself is gone. 
Would this still have weird implications? i kept trying to implement this as a function in `normal.c` yet i could not manage to make it work. 
Let me know.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -139,6 +141,8 @@ static char opchars[][3] = {
   { 'g', '@', OPF_CHANGE },              // OP_FUNCTION
   { Ctrl_A, NUL, OPF_CHANGE },           // OP_NR_ADD
   { Ctrl_X, NUL, OPF_CHANGE },           // OP_NR_SUB
+  { 'Q', NUL, OPF_LINES },               // OP_REGREPLAY
+  { '@', NUL, OPF_LINES },               // OP_ATREGREPLAY

comment_regular_data.body:
Not sure that it makes sense to pretend these are operators. This happens to add visual support but they don't work with motions or text objects... though that would be very cool to have (but is a more fundamental change).

https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/21422 suggests adding only default mappings. The tests from this PR could be used to test the default mappings.

Closing.
See #26495, that is far more comprehensive and equally tested.

title: feat(macros): repeat for visual mode
